content.description: This is the rightmost line on Warm-Up Wall adjacent to an arete. Long, small, vertical cracks run nearly the length of the wall.
content.location: Head to the East Area - the Warm-Up Wall is at the head of the minor draw formed by the small drainage behind a large tilted slab and small oaks.

content.description: This is the third clear problem along the Warm-Up Wall.
content.location: Head to the East Area - the Warm-Up Wall is at the head of the little draw right after you cross the dry drainage higher up. A massive tilted slab is just west of the wall (and provides the ideal spot to take photos).

content.description: This is the leftmost problem on Warm-Up Wall.
content.location: Head to the East Area - the Warm-Up Wall is at the head of the minor draw formed by the small drainage behind a large tilted slab and small oaks.

content.description: This is the leftmost problem on Warm-Up Wall. It is shorter than the Lines 1, 2, and 3 which are off to the right.
content.location: Head to the East Area - the Warm-Up Wall is at the head of the minor draw formed by the small drainage behind a large tilted slab and small oaks.

content.description:
One of the best lines in the Preserve is located on a van-sized boulder overlooking a bunch of brush.

Make your way up the gently overhanging feature on chalked, sloper ledges.
content.location: It is in the Western Area off the east side of Patrick's Point. The boulder is a big piece of the bedrock that has slumped off from the rest of the cliff. It can be easily reached by hiking west along the Rim Trail to the Point Trail and scrambling down to it (this avoids the majority of the brush). If you're coming from the Eastern Area, you'll likely be walking in the creek plain and will need to bushwhack through the thicker vegetation coming off the minor draw that separates the Central Area from Patrick's Point.

content.description: Sit start with your left hand on the arete and your right hand on the rail out right. This is a short but sweet line.
content.location:
It is nestled in between 2 boulders climber's left of

Don't Mind the Yucca

. The GPS coordinates should be pretty spot on: 37°19'38.6"N 108°35'37.8"W.

content.description: This climbs an easily negotiated 10-12 foot tall wall with lots of holds. It is a perfect spot for doing some warm-up traversing.
content.location: It is on the long, 10-12 foot tall, south-facing wall just west of the signpost area where the trail from the parking lot meets the rim.

content.description: The problem is a short slab with a T-shaped crack system running through the middle. Sit start with your hands in the crack and your feet on the small ledge. Work up the crack taking advantage of the good hold halfway up, then throw your right hand up to the horizontal crack/rail. Shoot for the top with your left hand, smear, then mantel up.
content.location:
This problem is located in the "Central Area" on a west-facing slab of sandstone halfway between the southeastern edge/corner of the Rim Route trail and Patrick Point where the rim straightens out east of the Patrick Point curve. It is part of a collection of short, potential problems nestled into a little pocket formed by the rim and a couple of split off boulders. It is West/around the corner from

Indoor Pinch

(V1).

content.description:
Sit start with your hands in the crack. Do a few laybacks and hand jams with good feet until your head is about at topout level. Reach left for good jugs on the top.

The landing is perfect - flat, no rocks.
content.location: This crack is located directly across the canyon from The Van Boulder.

content.description:
Sit start. Make a move up and right to a good crimp. Move your left hand to a jug in the crack, then work your way up the crack, crimping where it is wide enough. The crack extends to the top and then angles right, where it can be reached and used as a great hold for topping out.

This has a perfect, flat landing.
content.location: This crack is located directly across the canyon from The Van boulder. Also, located 10ft to the west (right) of the South Rim Hand Crack.

content.description:
Slabby McCactus Face is a fun, little run up a sharply angled, standalone boulder with a heavily dimpled face - and cactus strewn across the base!

Get your feet on good footholds above largest cactus patch, and dimple your way up the slab.

For a sane approach, grab an edge when you can, and make your way up. For a more adventurous approach, try to avoid the edges.

Get down by swinging around to the back of the slab.
content.location: A standalone boulder in the East Area midway along the path from the Warm-Up Wall south to the Overhang Feature.

content.description:
Skinny Dihedral is on the south side of the sharp notch feature; it is possibly the "tall, thin" problem described by Mike W.

Start with good feet in low pocket and your hands in good handhold in the crack. Get a high foot onto a ledge, stand, and reach up left. Then go right up to small horn off of the next horizontal strata, get your feet up high, stand, and top out.
content.location: It is in the East Area on the south side of a sharp notch feature that cuts into the cliff band.

content.description:
The Overhang - Right is one of the best lines in the Preserve.

Per Mike W.:

"A very obvious, overhanging feature, with chalked start holds off the ground. Match with a heelhook on these, and find your way up and right."
content.location: This is in the East Area. The Overhang is located at the southern end of the same north-south portion of the cliffline that houses the Warm-Up Wall. If the rocks are heading east-west, you've gone too far!

content.description:
The Overhand Left is one of the best lines in the Preserve and the one you see in all the pics here....

Per Mike W.:

"A very obvious, overhanging feature, with chalked start holds off the ground. Match with a heel hook on these, and find your way up and left.... Be careful when topping out, there's cacti."
content.location: It is in the East Area. The Overhang is located at the southern end of the same north-south portion of the cliffline that houses the Warm-Up Wall. If the rocks are heading east-west, you've gone too far!

content.description: Climb the face/cracks pictured in the topo.
content.location:
It's on the other side of the boulder from

Buzzsaw Traverse

.

content.description: Obtuse Slab is a nice run up a short, seemingly featureless, curved slab. Start by getting up on the broad ledge, getting your feet smeared on some scars, and work your way up, using the camouflaged ledge, sideways crimp, and vertical crack near the top to score the send.
content.location: In the East Area, this ascends a gently curving and extremely dark patinated slab on the left side of the Obtuse Corner.

content.description: Sit start with your left hand on horizontal crack, your right hand in vertical crack, and your feet on a small ledge. Get up, gain a left hand crimp out high on the arête/edge, and move your right hand to hand-sized pinch protruding from vertical crack. Get your feet up into pockets/gaps, grab the top, and mantel up.
content.location: It is in the "Central Area" along rim halfway between Patrick Point & the Rim Route Trail where the escarpment straightens out. This area is at the end of a 30 foot-long, man-sized crack running out of the rim bedrock to the rim edge, with the problem located on the west-facing/east side of the crack mouth.

content.description:
Hawkins Black-on-White is a fun problem with an overhanging start in a funky black and white mini-cave and a vertical finish.

Sit start on large sloper/pinch divot, and work up and out of the mini-cave on juggy pockets to a vertical section.
content.location: It is in the East Area south of a sharp notch and north of an obtuse corner.

content.description:
Sit start on a smooth block with a blue bonzai pine next to it. Traverse north using the lower sloper ledge and upper crimp ledge in the black streaks. Set up for a tensiony move to a good, right hand sidepull. Move your left hand to some crimps above the sidepull. Set up for a move to the knob on the arete. Top out straight up from here using holds on the face and the arete.

This has about 12-15 feet of traversing followed by an 8 foot topout.
content.location:
This boulder is located immediately off the cliff line on the western fenced boundary of Hawkins Preserve. It's overhung by about 15 degrees, and there is a silver swastika spray painted on the boulder along with other graffiti. There is a lot of broken glass on the ground around here.

There are other good climbs on the face of this boulder and the boulders nearby.

The GPS coordinates are: 37.327237, -108.600212.

content.description:
Double Chockstone has some fun stems down low and good hand holds for the topout.

I didn't see any signs of someone climbing it before me, but if I'm not the FA, just LMK.
content.protection: 1 or 2 pads. A spotter would be nice.
content.location:
It is a couple hundred feet east of the Overhang problems.

The GPS coordinates are: 37°19'38.2"N 108°35'37.3"W.

content.description: This is worth doing if you are in the area. It is a decent face climb. Don't fall on the yucca.
content.location:
It should be pretty easy to spot if you look for the yucca and the wall in the picture. It's maybe 50 - 100' climber's left (West) of

Double Chockstone

.

content.description:
Crimps On an Arête ascends a heavily textured arête feature found on the south end of the Warm-Up Wall.

Try to establish yourself at the seemingly featureless overhanging base, and use the tiny crimps, nubs, pockets, etc. to work your way up.
content.location: It is on the Southern end of the East Area Warm-Up Wall where a sharp notch cuts into the formation.

content.description:
Start on

Buzzsaw Arete

, work right until you reach the end of the face, then top out.
content.location:
Start on

Buzzsaw Arete

.

The coordinates are: 37°19'37.9"N 108°35'37.1"W.

content.description: Climb the jagged arete.
content.location:
It is about 50-ish' right (East) of

Double Chockstone

.

The coordinates are: 37°19'37.9"N 108°35'37.1"W.

content.description:
Beer Belly is a problem that works its way up the curved, three-lobe, white stone formation in the center of the Obtuse Corner dihedral.

Start with your hands underclinging the base of the beer belly and your feet on the dimple scars. Work your left hand up, massage the belly, use more foot dimples, grab an edge with your right hand, bring your left foot high, shoot for a left flake at the top, bring your feet up, and top out.
content.location: In the East Area, this climbs a funky formation in the middle of Obtuse Corner dihedral.
